Expectation1: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation1: Routine logs are updated on a flexible schedule, and this batch of results could be recorded later without issue.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my lab bench, heart thumping. The data from the latest experiment was still fresh in my mind, and I knew I should document every detail while it was clear. As a scientist, I prided myself on accuracy—my supervisor always said, “Timely notes make for reliable science.” But the routine logs could technically wait; I’d done it before without any real consequences. Still, the expectation to be thorough tugged at me.

Then my phone buzzed—a reminder for my volunteer shift at the community kitchen. I was supposed to be there in fifteen minutes. Punctuality mattered, but I also knew the first half-hour was always slow, and the other volunteers could handle things if I was a bit late. Yet, I’d promised myself and the coordinator I’d be reliable, not just another name on the roster.

I stood frozen, pen in hand, torn between the urge to finish my notes and the responsibility to show up for my shift. Both roles mattered to me, but right now, it felt impossible to do justice to both.
